,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: '''Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor''' (born 6 May 2019) is the son of [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex]], and [[Meghan, Duchess of Sussex]]. A great-grandchild of [[Queen Elizabeth II]], he is seventh in the [[line of succession to the British throne]].
Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor is the son of the [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex
column3: Duchess of Sussex]]. He was born at 05:26 [[British Summer Time
column5: UTC]]) on 6 May 2019 at the [[Portland Hospital]] in London.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Royal baby: Meghan gives birth to boy, Harry announces
column12: title=Duchess of Sussex gave birth at Portland Hospital in Westminster, royal baby's birth certificate confirms
column17: access-date=17 May 2019}}</ref> Several landmarks were illuminated in different colours to mark the birth, including [[Niagara Falls]], the [[CN Tower]] and the [[London Eye]].<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Niagara Falls will shine blue Monday to mark royal birth
column26: title=CN Tower lit in purple to mark birth of royal baby
column32: title=London Eye to turn red, white and blue for royal baby
column36: accessdate=7 May 2019}}</ref> His name was announced on 8 May 2019.<ref>{{cite news
column38: title=Royal baby: Duke and Duchess of Sussex name son Archie
column41: accessdate=8 May 2019}}</ref> He was [[baptised]], wearing the [[royal christening gown#United Kingdom
column42: royal christening gown]], by the [[Justin Welby
column43: Archbishop of Canterbury]] on 6 July 2019 in the Private Chapel of [[Windsor Castle]].<ref>{{cite news
column45: title=Harry and Meghan's baby Archie christened at Windsor

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Archie Mountbatten-Windsor is descended from the [[British royal family]] on his father's side and from the American [[American working class
column3: middle class]]es on [[Family of Meghan, Duchess of Sussex
column5: quote=Doria was born and raised in a middle-class African-American community of Los Angeles. She later earned a master’s degree in social work from the University of Southern California and became a yoga instructor.
column8: title=How Meghan Markle Was Destined for the Spotlight
column14: quote=She had a pretty American upper middle class existence, including a private elementary and secondary school education and an undergraduate degree from an elite American university.
column17: title=Meghan Markle is no modern-day Cinderella. She's better.
column22: quote=... he represents change for the oldest of houses. He is half American, descended on his mother’s side from a bellhop in a Cleveland hotel, a laundry worker in Chattanooga, and a bartender in an Atlanta saloon.
column27: title=Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Gives Birth to a Boy
column31: date=6 May 2019}}</ref> He is a citizen both [[citizen of the United Kingdom
column32: of the United Kingdom]] and [[Citizenship of the United States
column34: title=US tax authorities could stake a claim to Baby Sussex's inheritance

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: As Harry is not the eldest son of the Prince of Wales, his son is neither a [[British prince]] nor does he have the style Royal Highness. However, if and when Prince Charles becomes King, according to Letters Patent issued by George V in 1917, Harry's son, as the son of the son of the sovereign will have the right to the title of Prince and style of Royal Highness (although there is precedent for titles and styles of this nature to not be used, as in the case of [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex#Issue
column3: title=History of Royal Titles: HRH and Prince/Princess
column7: accessdate=27 February 2020}}</ref> There was the option of using Prince Harry's [[subsidiary title]] of Earl of Dumbarton, as a [[Courtesy titles in the United Kingdom
column8: courtesy]], but Meghan and Harry decided instead that he would be styled as [[Master (form of address)#Current usage in the United Kingdom
column11: title=Archie Harrison: The meaning behind the royal baby's name
column21: date=17 March 2016}}</ref> in accordance with their wish that he grow up as a private citizen.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=Harry and Meghan Name Their Son: Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor
column29: title=Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor – what's in a name?

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The ''' National Gridiron League''' ('''NGL''') is a professional spring gridiron football league with twelve teams based throughout the southeast and the mid-western United States. The NGL teams will play eighteen games per league season with individual player salary ranging from $6,0000 to $23,000 per player.
Initially the league announced that it had planned to start play as an [[Indoor American football
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: indoor football]] league in spring 2020, with 12 teams aligned in two divisions.

column5: access-date=February 28, 2020}}</ref> No home venues are confirmed to have been signed in any listed location although they are listed on the posted schedule.<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The ''' National Gridiron League''' ('''NGL''') is a proposed [[gridiron football]] league. Prior to the postponed 2019 season, the league logo used was a near copy of the former [[United Football League (2009–2012)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: United Football League]], while many of the team names and logos are also copies of former football teams. League chairman McClendon said that those trademarks had expired and it makes good business sense to recycle them in an attempt to capture the already existing fan-bases.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=New Roanoke arena football league tells city leaders league is still on track

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Initially the league announced that it had planned to start play as an [[Indoor American football
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: indoor football]] league in spring 2019, with 12 teams aligned in two divisions<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=June 25, 2018}}</ref> starting on March 30, 2019, and conclude with the inaugural Gridiron Bowl game on August 10, 2019, in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=March 2, 2019}}</ref> However, the league pushed back the announced start of the inaugural season to May 2019 amid reports the league has not had finalized leases for many of its teams.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Indiana Firebirds to play shorter schedule than originally planned
column16: title=Will arena football actually come to Roanoke?
column20: title=Arena football could return to region

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: By April 2, team coaches informed the players the season was canceled as the league was not going to be able to honor their original contracts and that none of the team staff or coaches had ever been paid.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Letter: Blue Bombers inaugural season canceled
column7: title=Blue Bombers coaches not paid a cent, amidst potential folding of NGL
column9: date=April 3, 2019}}</ref> League chairman Joe McClendon announced the following day that league had postponed its inaugural season to 2020 citing organizational changes in personnel and the suspension of operations of the [[Alliance of American Football]].<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Arkansas Twisters return pushed back to 2020
column13: date=April 3, 2019}}</ref> Its personnel later sued the league over their claims of non-payment for their work.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Former Indiana Firebirds president Jim Riggs sues National Gridiron League in federal court

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The league continued pursuits of a 2020 season including announcing player signings and scheduled Organized Team Activities (OTAs) for January 24–26, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=OTAS NEXT ON TAP FOR TEAMS
column5: date=December 20, 2019}}</ref> However, all OTAs were canceled the evening of January 24 after players had started arriving.<ref name = \"Evansville2020\">{{cite web
column7: title=National Gridiron League, Evansville indoor football team leave players stranded
column9: date=January 31, 2020}}</ref> The league then announced that teams would be allowed to play outdoors.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=NGL APPROVES TEAMS TO PLAY IN OUTDOOR VENUES
column13: date=February 28, 2020}}</ref> The 2020 season was postponed amidst the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=NGL TO DELAY 2020 START DUE TO HEALTH CONCERNS

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: <small>As of February 21, 2019. Cities in ''italics'' were locations identified by the league website, but no leases for an arena were confirmed to have been signed in the listed location.<ref>{{cite web

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su:
known_for = [[Grenfell Mission]]
[[Military Cross]]
[[Croix de Guerre]]
[[Military chaplain
column4: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]]

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: MC]] (1889-1964) was a British soldier and priest.  He served as an Officer in the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] during [[World War I]] for which he was [[mentioned in despatches]], awarded a [[Military Cross]] and the [[Croix de Guerre]], as Captain and subsequently Major of his Regiment.<ref name=\"auto6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Life story: Arthur Raley | Lives of the First World War
column7: title=Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador, volume 2 [Extract: letter Hac-Hoy] :: Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador
column13: title=A History of the Church Lads' Brigade in Newfoundland
column18: via=Google Books}}</ref>  After the [[World War I
column19: War]] he was ordained in [[England]] and later became [[Military chaplain
column21: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he held the relative rank of Squadron Leader and was again [[mentioned in despatches]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref name=\"auto\">https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf</ref><ref name=\"auto4\">https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/34636/page/4049/data.pdf</ref>  Prior to [[World War I]], Raley worked on the [[Grenfell Mission]] in [[Labrador]], [[Canada]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Arthur Raley was born at [[Barnsley]], [[England]] in 1889.<ref name=\"auto5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  He was educated at [[Bedford Modern School]] where, as an accomplished cricketer, he was in the first XI in 1905 and 1906.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Community: Bedford Modern School - Eagle Magazine extracts | Lives of the First World War
column11: website=livesofthefirstworldwar.iwm.org.uk}}</ref>  He played in a cricket match with [[W. G. Grace]] shortly after leaving school.<ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>http://www.hemsworthgrammarschool.org/Downloadable%20Files/School%20History%201932a.pdf</ref>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: After school, Raley trained as a surveyor but gave it up and emigrated to [[Newfoundland]], [[Canada]], on his 21st birthday, with the ultimate aim of being ordained.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He initially worked as a schoolmaster at what is now [[Bishop Feild College]] in [[Newfoundland]] before joining the [[Grenfell Mission]] and being sent to northern [[Labrador]] where he took command of a reindeer ranch organising medical supplies and assistance to remote communities.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

Raley joined the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] but when [[World War I]] was declared, he signed up with the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] as a Lieutenant on 24 September 1914.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Lieutenant Owen William Steele of the Newfoundland Regiment
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  As part of the [[Mediterranean Expeditionary Force]] he saw action in [[Gallipoli]], having landed at [[Suvla Bay]], and was promoted Captain on 28 July 1915 and Adjutant on 29 September 1915.<ref name=\"auto7\"/><ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>{{Cite web

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was admitted to hospital in [[Malta]] on 13 December 1915 but rejoined the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Regiment]] at [[Suez]] on 31 January 1916.<ref name=\"auto7\"/>  His Regiment was part of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)
column3: British Expeditionary Force]] on 14 March 1916 and Raley was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 1 January 1917.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref name=\"auto7\"/>  The citation for his [[Military Cross]] read:'For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.  He organised and gallantly led a bombing attack driving the enemy back at a critical time.  He set a splendid example of courage and initiative'.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref>https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_0-149.pdf</ref>

column4: Capt. A Raley (left) leading the Royal Newfoundland Regiment across the Rhine into Germany, 1918]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was wounded at [[Monchy-le-Preux]] during the [[Battle of Arras (1917)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Battle of Arras]] in April 1917 after which he returned to [[England]] to convalesce.<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column9: via=Google Books}}</ref>  On 23 May 1917, he was attached to the Depot, Ayr, and rejoined his Regiment on 26 January 1918.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Following the Armistice, Captain Raley and Lt. Col. A.E. Bernard led the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] across the Rhine into Germany on 13 December 1918.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=www.heritage.nf.ca}}</ref>  He was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] in 1919.<ref>https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/31409/supplement/7805/data.pdf</ref>  He was appointed Second in Command of the 1st Battalion of his Regiment in May 1919 before his return to Newfoundland.<ref name=\"auto2\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: According to ''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]]'', Raley returned to England and entered Theological College after which he was made Deacon of the Church of All Saints Luton where he became a Priest in 1924.<ref name=\"auto3\">{{Cite web
column6: via=Google Books}}</ref>  For the next fifteen years he worked as a parish priest at Christ Church Luton and as Vicar of Grimethorpe (1931-49).<ref name=\"auto2\"/><ref name=\"auto3\"/><ref>https://www.barnsleybenefice.org/content/pages/documents/1461176117.pdf</ref>

column3: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he was again [[mentioned in despatches]] and had the relative rank of Squadron Leader.<ref name=\"auto\"/><ref name=\"auto4\"/>  He left his Vicarship at Grimethorpe in 1949,<ref>The London Gazette, 8 March 1949, p.1203</ref> but remained Vicar of St Edward’s Church Barnsley until 1961.<ref name=\"auto3\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In 1960, Raley was honoured by his old school, being made President of the [[Bedford Modern School
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Old Bedford Modernians’ Club]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He died in [[Bedford]] in 1964.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column6: publisher=National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: [[Category:Canadian military personnel of World War I]]
[[Category:British military personnel of World War I]]
[[Category:British military personnel of World War II]]
[https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf Certain papers concerning Major Arthur Raley MC]","{{Use dmy dates

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: MC]] (1889-1964) was a British soldier and priest.  He served as an Officer in the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] during [[World War I]] for which he was [[mentioned in despatches]], awarded a [[Military Cross]] and the [[Croix de Guerre]], as Captain and subsequently Major of his Regiment.<ref name=\"auto6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Life story: Arthur Raley | Lives of the First World War
column7: title=Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador, volume 2 [Extract: letter Hac-Hoy] :: Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador
column13: title=A History of the Church Lads' Brigade in Newfoundland
column18: via=Google Books}}</ref>  After the [[World War I
column19: War]] he was ordained and later became [[Military chaplain
column21: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he had the relative rank of Squadron Leader and was again [[mentioned in despatches]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref name=\"auto\">https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf</ref><ref name=\"auto4\">https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/34636/page/4049/data.pdf</ref>  Prior to [[World War I]], Raley worked on the [[Grenfell Mission]] in [[Labrador]], [[Canada]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Arthur Raley was born at [[Barnsley]], [[England]] in 1889.<ref name=\"auto5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  He was educated at [[Bedford Modern School]] where, as an accomplished cricketer, he was in the first XI in 1905 and 1906.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Community: Bedford Modern School - Eagle Magazine extracts | Lives of the First World War
column11: website=livesofthefirstworldwar.iwm.org.uk}}</ref>  He played in a cricket match with [[W. G. Grace]] shortly after leaving school.<ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>http://www.hemsworthgrammarschool.org/Downloadable%20Files/School%20History%201932a.pdf</ref>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: After school, Raley trained as a surveyor but gave it up and emigrated to [[Newfoundland]], [[Canada]], on his 21st birthday, with the ultimate aim of being ordained.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He initially worked as a schoolmaster at what is now [[Bishop Feild College]] in [[Newfoundland]] before joining the [[Grenfell Mission]] and being sent to northern [[Labrador]] where he took command of a reindeer ranch organising medical supplies and assistance to remote communities.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

Raley joined the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] but when [[World War I]] was declared, he signed up with the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] as a Lieutenant on 24 September 1914.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Lieutenant Owen William Steele of the Newfoundland Regiment
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  As part of the [[Mediterranean Expeditionary Force]] he saw action in [[Gallipoli]], having landed at [[Suvla Bay]], and was promoted Captain on 28 July 1915 and Adjutant on 29 September 1915.<ref name=\"auto7\"/><ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>{{Cite web

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was admitted to hospital in [[Malta]] on 13 December 1915 but rejoined the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Regiment]] at [[Suez]] on 31 January 1916.<ref name=\"auto7\"/>  His Regiment was part of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)
column3: British Expeditionary Force]] on 14 March 1916 and Raley was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 1 January 1917.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref name=\"auto7\"/>  The citation for his [[Military Cross]] read:<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref>https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_0-149.pdf</ref>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.  He organised and gallantly led a bombing attack driving the enemy back at a critical time.  He set a splendid example of courage and initiative.

column4: Capt. A Raley (left) leading the Royal Newfoundland Regiment across the Rhine into Germany, 1918]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was wounded at [[Monchy-le-Preux]] during the [[Battle of Arras (1917)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Battle of Arras]] in April 1917 after which he returned to [[England]] to convalesce.<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column9: via=Google Books}}</ref>  On 23 May 1917, he was attached to the Depot, Ayr, and rejoined his Regiment on 26 January 1918.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Following the Armistice, Captain Raley and Lt. Col. A.E. Bernard led the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] across the Rhine into Germany on 13 December 1918.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=www.heritage.nf.ca}}</ref>  He was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] in 1919.<ref>https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/31409/supplement/7805/data.pdf</ref>  He was appointed Second in Command of the 1st Battalion of his Regiment in May 1919 before his return to Newfoundland.<ref name=\"auto2\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: According to ''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]]'', Raley returned to England and entered Theological College after which he was made Deacon of the Church of All Saints Luton where he became a Priest in 1924.<ref name=\"auto3\">{{Cite web
column6: via=Google Books}}</ref>  For the next fifteen years he worked as a parish priest at Christ Church Luton and as Vicar of Grimethorpe (1931-49).<ref name=\"auto2\"/><ref name=\"auto3\"/><ref>https://www.barnsleybenefice.org/content/pages/documents/1461176117.pdf</ref>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: '''Minnesota Youth Symphonies''', commonly referred to as '''MYS''', was founded in 1972 by Ralph Winkler. The program has four [[orchestra]]s composed of students from elementary level through high school,<ref name=classical>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref> with participation's based on an annual audition. MYS, led by co-artistic directors Manny and Claudette Laureano since 1988, performs at [[Orchestra Hall (Minneapolis)
column7: Orchestra Hall]] in [[Minneapolis]], as well as other locations, and hosts workshops and classes.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Participation is based on an [[audition]] in which the prospective student must perform an appropriate solo, orchestral excerpt, scales and arpeggios, and must sight-read.
The orchestras perform three major concerts in the Twin Cities area, primarily at [[Orchestra Hall (Minneapolis)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Orchestra Hall]] in [[Minneapolis]]. There are also other performance opportunities throughout the year. Every fall the orchestras host the Symphony Solo Competition; the winners of the competition perform at the Symphony Orchestra's spring concert.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=5.6.07: Minnesota Youth Symphonies Soloists at Orchestra Hall

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In addition to performances, MYS hosts workshops and classes, and an annual summer music program, that usually consists of a chamber string workshop and a composition workshop. The MYS Symphony Orchestra has historically, recently, and will continue to tour internationally. The most recent trip was to Cuba in the summer of 2017

The String Orchestra is gauged for the intermediate playing level for only those who play the violin, cello, or bass. The orchestra provides these players with a comprehensive string ensemble experience. The literature for the students is designed to broaden their repertoire and learn more advanced techniques for both playing and following a condcutor. The students learn how to successfully navigate difficult passages on their instrument and learn how to listen for orchestral intonation.
The Philharmonic Orchestra, which is designed to be a full symphony [[orchestra
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: ]], is placed at the advanced intermediate playing level. The literature is a combination of arranged and unedited works designed to expose students to a symphony orchestra experience. During rehearsals, there is time set aside for sectionals to iron out specific passages along with exploring different ways to play a passage and nuances to the piece.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Pieces that have been played by the Philharmonic Orchestra include ''[[Carmen Suites (Bizet/Guiraud)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Carmen Suites]]'' by [[Georges Bizet]], ''Dance of the Tumblers from [[The Snow Maiden
column3: The Snow Maiden]]'' by [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]], a [[Merle J. Isaac
column4: Merle J. Isaac]] arrangment of ''Dance Infernale, Berceuse and Finale'' from ''[[The Firebird

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The Repertory Orchestra is also designed to be a full symphony orchestra and is placed at the advanced level. Most, if not all, the literature in this orhcestra is unedited. The orchestra helps players refine advanced playing techniques in both sectionals and full-orchestra rehearsals.
The orchestra's repertoire includes the ''Overture'' from ''[[Candide (operetta)
column10: Symphony No. 9]]'' (From the New World) by [[Antonín Dvořák
column13: Symphony No. 4]]'' both by [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The Symphony Orchestra is also designed to be a symphony orchestra and plays at a collegiate level. The orchestra is considered the top orchestra in program. The program explores, in-depth, the many ways to interpret a phrase and other complex musical aspects. The orchestra also has an annual Symphony Solo Competition; the two winners of this competition perform their selected movement of their piece to perform with the Symphony Orchestra.
A few highlights of the orchestra's repertoire include ''[[Scheherazade (Rimsky-Korsakov)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Scheherazade]]'' by Rimksy-Korsakov, ''[[The Rite of Spring
column3: The Rite of Spring]]'' by Stravinsky, ''[[The Planets

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: MYS has been under the artistic direction of [[Manny Laureano]], principal trumpet of the [[Minnesota Orchestra]], and his wife, Claudette Laureano, director of the [[Breck School]]'s String Program, since 1988.<ref name=classical /> Previous music/artistic directors have included Ralph Winkler, Ed Forner (former Assistant Conductor with the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra and Professor of Music at [[Macalester College]]), [[Bill McGlaughlin]], Clyn D. Barrus and David Tubergen. Under Winkler and Forner's initial leadership, MYS grew from a single orchestra to three ensembles ranging from beginning students to college-level musicians. MYS grew to four orchestras and over 400 students under the Laureanos' leadership and MYS became known nationally as one of the nation's leading youth symphony organizations, adding a summer program and community outreach programs serving over 600 students.{{citation needed

Several alumni of the Minnesota Youth Symphonies program hold positions with professional orchestras, such as the [[Boston Symphony]], [[Cleveland Orchestra]], [[San Francisco Symphony]], [[Minnesota Orchestra]], the [[Dallas Symphony Orchestra]], the [[Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra]] and the [[Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra]].{{citation needed
In 1972, the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra Society ended its sponsorship of the St. Paul Youth Orchestra, and Ralph Winkler established a new youth orchestra, the Minnesota Youth Symphony.

MYS toured [[Romania]] in 1973, becoming the first American youth orchestra to tour in a communist country. In 1992, the MYS Symphony Orchestra became the first orchestra to perform in the Super Bowl's half-time show, when [[Super Bowl XXVI]] was played at the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] in Minneapolis.<ref name=classical /> [[Elmer Bernstein]] guest-conducted \"The Magnificent Seven\" with the MYS Philharmonic Orchestra in 1997. MYS has collaborated with many noted guest artists, conductors and performing groups including Minnesota Orchestra Music Director [[Osmo Vänskä]], [[Butch Thompson]], Charles Lazarus, [[Jorja Fleezanis]], [[Bel Canto Chorus]], St. Paul City Ballet, Minnesota Boys Choir, Ignacio \"Nachito\" Herrera, [[Doc Severinsen]] and the T.C. Swing Dancers.<ref name=classical /> In the winter of 2007, MYS Symphony Orchestra, under the baton of Manny Laureano, performed Stravinsky's ''[[Rite of Spring]]'' in concert at Orchestra Hall, which was a first for MYS.

The 2007/08 season marked the 35th anniversary of MYS as well as the 20th anniversary of co-artistic directors Claudette and Manny Laureano. In honor of these events, each of the Minnesota Youth Symphonies' four orchestras premiered original works by Minnesotan composers. Full orchestral pieces were commissioned from composers [[Stephen Paulus]], Shelley Hanson and MYS alumnus Edward (Teddy) Niedermaier. To select the fourth work, MYS held a composition competition open to MYS students and alumni under the age of 21. Aaron Hirsch, of [[Sleepy Eye, Minnesota
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Sleepy Eye]], Minnesota won this contest with his composition for string orchestra.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nachito Herrera and Manny Laureano perform with the Minnesota Youth Symphonies

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In 2015, MYS was invited to take part in the opening concerts at the newly renovated [[Ordway Center for the Performing Arts]]. During the two-year [[renovation]] of Orchestra Hall, MYS performed in various venues around the Twin Cities, such as churches and concert halls.
In 2017, the MYS Symphony Orchestra toured the Cuba, on the heels of the Minnesota Orchestra's historic tour.
[[Category:Youth organizations based in Minnesota]]","{{more citations needed

Full orchestral pieces were commissioned from composers [[Stephen Paulus]], Shelley Hanson and MYS alumnus Edward (Teddy) Niedermaier. To select the fourth work, MYS held a composition competition open to MYS students and alumni under the age of 21. Aaron Hirsch, of [[Sleepy Eye, Minnesota
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Sleepy Eye]], Minnesota won this contest with his composition for string orchestra.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nachito Herrera and Manny Laureano perform with the Minnesota Youth Symphonies

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In 2015, MYS was invited to take part in the opening concerts at the newly renovated [[Ordway Center for the Performing Arts]]. During the two-year [[renovation]] of Orchestra Hall, MYS performed in various venues around the Twin Cities, such as churches and concert halls.
In 2017, the MYS Symphony Orchestra toured the Cuba, on the heels of the Minnesota Orchestra's historic tour.

Bieber attended [[Laguna Hills High School]] in [[Laguna Hills, California]]. Bieber's pitch speed reached the mid-80s as a junior and his [[Glossary_of_baseball_(C)#command

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: The state of consciousness leading out of sleep}}

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The '''hypnopompic state''' (or '''hypnopompia''') is the [[state of consciousness]] leading out of [[sleep]], a term coined by the [[psychical researcher]] [[Frederic William Henry Myers
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Frederic Myers]]. Its mirror is the [[hypnagogic]] state at sleep onset; though often conflated, the two states are not identical. The hypnagogic state is [[Rationality
column4: waking]] [[cognition]] trying to make sense of non-linear images and associations; the hypnopompic state is [[emotion]]al and credulous [[dream]]ing cognition trying to make sense of real world stolidity. They have a different [[Phenomenology (philosophy)
column5: phenomenological]] character. While these hypnopompic hallucinations can be neutral, they are often more akin to nightmares. Further, they are frequently accompanied by e.g. [[sleep paralysis]], which is a state wherein the mind perceives itself to be awake, yet is unable to move the body, a truly terrifying disconnect between the soul and body. As such, hypnopompic hallucinations are deeply troubling experiences that for centuries now, have fascinated thinkers—most recently psychologists and increasingly now neurologists as well. Though the phenomena was once poorly understood it is now being illuminated by our growing understanding of sleep overall and in particular, our cutting edge brain-scanning technologies.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: To better understand hypnopompic hallucinations, we must first define [[hallucination]]s. These are commonly understood as “sensory perceptions that occur in the absence of an objective stimulus”.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite book
column21: editor3-first=Michael J.}}</ref> As this definition implies, though like dreams most hallucinations are '''visual''', they can encompass a broader range of sensory experience. '''Auditory''' hallucinations are thus also common: “patients can hear simple sounds, structured melodies or complete sentences”.<ref>{{Citation
column27: work=Principles and Practice of Sleep Medicine
column31: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> Slightly less common but not unheard of are '''“[[Somesthetic illusion
column32: somesthetic]]”''' hallucinations involving our sense of touch and location, with such experiences ranging from tactile sensations to full-blown '''“[[Cenesthopathy
column33: cenesthopathic]]”''' or '''\"out-of-body experiences\"''', which involve sudden changes in the perception of the body’s location, or even a sense of movement of the entire body. Finally, a unique characteristic of hypnopompic hallucinations is that as opposed to dreams, wherein we rarely understand we’re asleep, here sleepers do indeed have “the clear subjective awareness of being awake” yet are frequently mentally and physically trapped in the experience.<ref name=\":0\" />

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The objective difference between the subjective experiences of dreams and hypnopompic hallucinations emerges from a close look at our sleep cycle and its attendant brain activity: there are essentially '''two types of sleep''', [[Rapid eye movement sleep
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: REM sleep]], which is indeed categorised by [[Rapid eye movement sleep
column3: “rapid eye movement]]” and [[Non-rapid eye movement sleep
column4: NREM]], which stands for “Non-REM”. Now, in the first type of sleep, our brains are extremely active. In particular, during this stage, both our brain stem, which is the home of our most fundamental physical drives, and the parts of the cortex related to our most complex logical-cognitive functions experience highly '''intense''' electrical activity. As this perhaps suggests, REM is where the majority of dreaming occurs—it’s been all but confirmed at this point that [[dream]]s originate in the brain stem, a spark from there driving our more logical mind to contemplate and consolidate, through dreaming, memories that relate to fulfilling our fundamental drives. Conversely, there is almost no electrical activity during NREM sleep. It will thus be no surprise that NREM is what is referred to in layman’s terms as “[[Slow-wave sleep
column5: deep sleep]]”, which is characterised by the complete quieting of the mind, to include dreamlessness and by muscle “[[Atony
column6: atonia]]”, which is to basically say paralysis, a complete motor disconnect. A last critical point in this regard is that REM sleep cycles are bookended by NREM stages, which is to say that when we fall asleep and wake up, we first fall into and last arise from, NREM sleep.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite journal
column22: title=What Is the Link Between Hallucinations, Dreams, and Hypnagogic–Hypnopompic Experiences?

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: It is precisely at this last point, though, that a minor '''glitch''', as it were, in brain chemistry, can cause hypnopompic hallucinations: occasionally during deep NREM, “transient patterns of neural activation in brainstem structures resemble[ing] micro-wake “fragments” can occur”.<ref name=\":1\" /> As the origin of the fragments and their name implies, they have a twofold effect: first, just as in REM sleep, these brain stem fragments essentially activate the dream mechanism. Second, they indeed catalyse a near-waking state. However, this spark is often not powerful enough to jar us completely out of deep sleep, and so only our mind fully awakens, leaving our body trapped in the '''atonia of deep sleep'''. Another reason why hypnopompic hallucinations are often such horrible experiences, is because micro-wake fragments appear to be related to [[serotonin]] and [[dopamine]] deficits—these deficits predispose us to negative mental states, which likely causes the hallucinations to resemble our worst dreams.<ref name=\":1\" />

These mental experiences are indeed often deeply damaging: across cultures, the experience of hypnopompic hallucinations are strongly related to “visitations of spirits, demons or other grotesque creatures belonging to traditional folklore”.<ref name=\":0\" /> Thus, in the Anglosphere, hypnopompic experiences often entail the sense that an '''“[[Old hag
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Old Hag]]”''' or some similar '''“nocturnal spirit”''' is sitting on the sleeper’s chest, inducing both paralysis and an increasing, suffocating inability to move. Anthropologists have discovered references dating back to the High Middle ages of similar figures in Anglo-Saxon and Anglo-Norman traditions, most prominently the '''“''[[Maera (hound)
column3: mæra]]”''''' from the name of which figure we derive the word '''“nightmare”''', and which appears to have roots in ancient Germanic superstitions.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Similarly, subjects belonging to '''Yoruban-African diasporas''' report feeling as though they are being '''“ridden”''' by the evil manifestations of their versions of the African pantheon—ridden is the vernacular for possession by the gods, who are often referred to as '''“divine horsemen”'''. Interestingly in this vein, African-American communities that have been reliably linked to the Yoruba peoples, appear to conflate the cultural interpretation of the experience, referring to “being ridden by the witch”. Perhaps most chilling of all, though, are the Japanese interpretations of the experience, which are often grouped under the heading of '''''kanashibari''','' which translates loosely to '''“buried alive and bound in metal”'''.<ref name=\":0\" />

Owing to similarities between hypnagogic hallucinations and those experienced by sufferers from dementia, parkinson’s and schizophrenia, significant progress is being made on understanding the '''neurobiological basis''' of this experience. To illustrate, researchers have identified “a common neurofunctional substrate [which] points to a shared pattern of brain activation” underlying elements of '''schizophrenic delusions''' and these near-waking hallucinations: “with regional grey matter blood flow values being maximally increased in right parietal-occipital regions” during hypnagogic hallucinations and many schizoid episodes. There is reason to believe, then, that such painful near-waking experiences could soon be rendered '''obsolete'''.<ref name=\":0\" />

* T. Balkin, A. Braun, et al., \"The process of awakening: A PET study of regional brain activity patterns mediating the reestablishment of alertness and consciousness,\" ''Brain'', vol. 125, 2002, pp. 2308–19.
* P. Tassi and A. Muzet, \"Sleep inertia,\" ''Sleep Medicine Review'', vol. 4, no. 4, 2000, pp. 341–53.

column3: title=The Head Trip: Adventures on the Wheel of Consciousness

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: album      = [[When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?]]
prev_title = [[No Time to Die (Billie Eilish song)

all lowercase]]) is a song by American singer [[Billie Eilish]] from her debut studio album ''[[When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?]]''. It was written by Eilish and her brother Finneas O'Connell, who also produced the song. The song peaked at number 62 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100
column8: accessdate=11 March 2020}}</ref> and charted in the top 100 in multiple countries. It was also certified gold in Australia, Canada, and the United States.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: It is preceded by \"[[Bury a Friend]]\" on its parent album, and the beginning instrumental of \"Ilomilo\" is featured at the end of its preceding track. The song impacted contemporary hit radio in Italy on April 10, 2020. But was actually released on March 29.<ref name = radio>{{Cite web
The song was inspired by the computer game [[ilomilo]], which is a 2010 puzzle game where the goal is to reunite two characters named \"Ilo\" and \"Milo\".<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=BILLIE EILISH'S WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP: A COMPLETE BREAKDOWN FROM FINNEAS O'CONNELL
column8: access-date=April 10, 2020}}</ref> The song was also partially inspired by the novel and film ''Bridge to Terabithia''.<ref>https://twitter.com/eilishupdates/status/1159608493453824001</ref> Eilish states: \"I used to play ilomilo a lot. I loved ilomilo, that was like my favorite game in the world. It's this game where it's these two little creatures – one is named ilo and the other's named milo. It's this sort of anti-gravity world where there's all these little blocks and they start apart from each other. The idea is you just get to each other and when they get to each other they just hug, there's no prize.\"<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Billie Eilish reveals the adorable story and meaning behind her 'ilomilo' lyrics

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In an Interview with ''MTV'', Finneas states that \"I like songs that exist with the knowledge of other songs. They're not linked in that they need each other to exist, necessarily, but they're like two different episodes of the same TV show. Just little fun things like bleeding songs into each other, those make it feel like a full album.\"<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=BILLIE EILISH'S WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP: A COMPLETE BREAKDOWN FROM FINNEAS O'CONNELL

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The song is a mid tempo song  that is played in the key of [[C minor]], while Eilish's vocals span a range of G<sub>3</sub> to A<sub>b4</sub>. The first half is moderately fast at 120 beats per minute (BPM). The genre of the song was Alternative Pop/Rock and Indie Pop<ref name=\"notes\">{{cite news

\"Ilomilo\" is about a person being separated from someone they love dearly and are trying to find them again. In it, Billie sings lines like: \"I don't wanna be lonely\" and \"I can't lose another life\". She also appears to reference a failed relationship by adding: \"I just wanted to protect you, but now I'll never get to.\" The person is afraid that their loved one will depart and never return. The person believes that the love they share is incomparable to what he will find in the outside world. Ultimately the song finishes with the chorus, where the person has been realized they are alone and their loved one is gone. The person is unaware of their location and wonders if they'll ever return. The persons desire for their loved one to “come home” is so strong that they don't even care if they are such under false pretenses. <ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Billie Eilish reveals the adorable story and meaning behind her 'ilomilo' lyrics
column8: access-date=April 9, 2020}}</ref> The song is introduced during the final seconds of \"Bury a Friend.\" There are lyrical reference to \"Bury a Friend\" in \"Ilomilo\": \"The friends I've had to bury, they keep me up at night\". Fans have speculated that the two songs are linked, but Finneas says the connection is more about making the album sound cohesive.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=BILLIE EILISH'S WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP: A COMPLETE BREAKDOWN FROM FINNEAS O'CONNELL

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: \"Ilomilo\" was met with critical appraise. In 2020, Insider placed the song at number 13 on their ''Every Billie Eilish song, ranked'' list, with Libby Torres calling it \"a catchy, mid tempo song with insanely relatable lyrics.\"<ref>{{cite web
column3: title = Every Billie Eilish song, ranked
column4: author = Callie Ahlgrim, Libby Torres and Claudia Willen
column7: website = Insider}}</ref> ''Circa the Future'' called it \"an underrated song\" and that \"her delicate vocals shine in this stunning song\"<ref>{{cite web
column12: website = Circa the future}}</ref> ''[[Stereogum]]''{{'s}} Chris DeVille called the song a \"skittering\" track and that the song seems to be grappling with her place in a world wrecked by tragedy.<ref>{{cite news

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Upon the release of ''When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?'', \"Ilomilo\" debuted at number 62 on the US ''Billboard'' [[Billboard Hot 100
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Hot 100]] for a week during April of 2019. It also made the top 100 in multiple countries including: Australia, Canada, Germany, Sweden, and the Netherlands. It was also certified gold in Canada, Australia and the United States.

all lowercase]]) is a song by American singer [[Billie Eilish]] from her debut studio album ''[[When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?]]''. It was written by Eilish and her brother Finneas O'Connell, who also produced the song. The song peaked at number 62 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100
column8: accessdate=11 March 2020}}</ref> and charted in the top 100 in multiple countries. It was also certified gold in Australia, Canada, and the United States.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: It is preceded by \"[[Bury a Friend]]\" on its parent album, and the beginning instrumental of \"Ilomilo\" is featured at the end of its preceding track. The song impacted contemporary hit radio in Italy on April 10, 2020.<ref name = radio>{{Cite web
The song was inspired by the computer game [[ilomilo]], which is a 2010 puzzle game where the goal is to reunite two characters named \"Ilo\" and \"Milo\".<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=BILLIE EILISH'S WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP: A COMPLETE BREAKDOWN FROM FINNEAS O'CONNELL
column8: access-date=April 10, 2020}}</ref> The song was also partially inspired by the novel and film ''Bridge to Terabithia''.<ref>https://twitter.com/eilishupdates/status/1159608493453824001</ref> Eilish states: \"I used to play ilomilo a lot. I loved ilomilo, that was like my favorite game in the world. It's this game where it's these two little creatures – one is named ilo and the other's named milo. It's this sort of anti-gravity world where there's all these little blocks and they start apart from each other. The idea is you just get to each other and when they get to each other they just hug, there's no prize.\"<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Billie Eilish reveals the adorable story and meaning behind her 'ilomilo' lyrics

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In an Interview with ''MTV'', Finneas states that \"I like songs that exist with the knowledge of other songs. ,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: '''Kirtland's snake''' (''Clonophis kirtlandii'') is a threatened or endangered (depending on location) [[North America]]n [[species]] of nonvenomous [[snake]] of the subfamily [[Natricinae]], of the family [[Colubridae]].<ref>{{EMBL species
column3: species=kirtlandii}} www.reptile-database.org.</ref> It is the only species in the [[genus]] ''[[Clonophis]]''.<ref>\"''Clonophis kirtlandii'' \". ITIS (Integrated Taxonomic Information System). www.itis.gov.</ref>

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: specific name]], ''kirtlandii'', is in honor of Dr. [[Jared Potter Kirtland]], an American [[naturalist]] of the Nineteenth Century.<ref>Beltz, Ellin (2006). Scientific and Common Names of the Reptiles and Amphibians of North America – Explained. ebeltz.net/herps/biogappx.html#K.</ref><ref>Beolens, Bo; Michael Watkins; Michael Grayson (2011). ''The Eponym Dictionary of Reptiles''. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. xiii + 296 pp. {{ISBN
column3: 978-1-4214-0135-5}}. (''Clonophis kirtlandi'', p. 142).</ref> The snake was first identified by [[Robert Kennicott]] in 1855. Kennicott sent a specimen to [[Spencer Fullerton Baird]], the assistant secretary of the [[Smithsonian Institution]], who offered to publish a description of the animal in Kennicott's name. Baird suggested ''Regina kirtlandii'' as a scientific name, as Kirtland had been a mentor to Kennicott.<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=The Early Career of Robert Kennicott, Illinois' Pioneering Naturalist

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: [[Common names]] for ''C. kirtlandii'' include: Cora Kennicott's snake, Kirtland's red snake, Kirtland's water snake, little red snake, Ohio Valley water snake, and spread head.<ref name=\"Wright&Wright1957\">[[Albert Hazen Wright
column3: A.A. Wright]] (1957). ''Handbook of Snakes of the United States and Canada''. Ithaca and London: Comstock. 1,105 pp. (in 2 volumes) (''Natrix kirtlandi'', pp. 496-499, Figure 146 + Map 40 on p. 491).</ref>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Kirtland's snake is small and slender. Adults reach a total length (including tail) of 12-18 inches (30–46 cm). It is grayish brown with a double series of large black spots down the back, and alternating smaller spots running down each side.<ref>[[George Albert Boulenger
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Boulenger, G.A.]] (1893). ''Catalogue of the Snakes in the British Museum (Natural History). Volume I., Containing the Families ... Colubridæ Aglyphæ, part.'' London: Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History). (Taylor and Francis, printers). xiii + 448 pp. + Plates I.- XXVIII. (''Ischnognathus kirtlandii'', p. 286).</ref>  The [[ventral scales]] are brick red with a prominent round black spot at each outer end.<ref name=\"Conant1975\">[[Roger Conant (herpetologist)
column3:
Conant, R.]] (1975). ''A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America, Second Edition''. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. xviii + 429 pp. + Plates 1-48.
{{ISBN
column5: 0-395-19977-8}} (paperback). (''Natrix kirtlandi'', p. 151 + Plate 22 + Map 106).</ref> It has 19 rows of [[Keeled scales
column6: keeled]] [[dorsal scales]] at midbody, and the [[Anal scale
column7: anal plate]] is divided.<ref>[[Hobart Muir Smith
column8: Smith, H.M.]], and [[Edmund D. Brodie, Jr.
column9: E.D. Brodie, Jr.]] (1982). ''Reptiles of North America: A Guide to Field Identification''. New York: Golden Press. 240 pp. {{ISBN

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Kirtland's snake is found in [[Illinois]], [[Indiana]], northern [[Kentucky]], southern [[Michigan]], [[Ohio]], and western [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name=\"Conant1975\"/>

The preferred natural [[habitat]]s of ''C. kirtlandii'' are [[forest]], [[grassland]], and [[wetlands]]<ref name=iucn/> such as [[swamp]]s and [[marsh]]es. It is almost always found very close to a water source, even though it is less [[aquatic animal
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: aquatic]] than water snakes of the genus ''[[Nerodia]]'' which share its geographic range.<ref name=\"Wright&Wright1957\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The species ''Clonophis kirtlandii'' is listed as endangered in [[Indiana]],<ref name=312iac>{{citation
column4: title=312 IAC 9-5-4: Endangered species of reptiles and amphibians
column7: url=http://www.in.gov/legislative/iac/}}.</ref>  [[Michigan]], and [[Pennsylvania]].<ref>Pennsylvania Fish & Boat Commission.</ref> It is listed as threatened in [[Illinois]] and [[Ohio]], though current research in Ohio is leaning towards the snake being listed as vulnerable.{{citation needed

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Kirtland's snake feeds on primarily [[crayfish]], along with the occasional [[earthworm]], [[slug]], [[minnow]], [[salamander]], [[frog]] and [[toad]].<ref name=\"Wright&Wright1957\"/>
Kirtland's snake may have a venom adapted towards killing crayfish.{{citation needed
When alarmed ''C. kirtlandii'' flattens its entire body to a remarkable thinness, and becomes rigid.<ref>[[Karl Patterson Schmidt
column3: D.D. Davis]] (1941). ''Field Book of Snakes of the United States and Canada''. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. 365 pp. (''Natrix kirtlandii'', pp. 209-210 + Plate 22, Center, on p. 342).</ref> Kirtland's snake will also coil up into a disc the size of about a quarter in an attempt to hide from potential threats. If this does not succeed, it will then flee instead of fight.{{citation needed

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: No person on record has ever been bitten by a Kirtland's snake. This species prefers intimidation, hiding, and fleeing rather than any form of fighting.{{citation needed

Kirtland's snake is [[ovoviviparous]]. Females give birth in August and September. Brood size varies from 4 to 22. Each newborn is 13–17 cm (5-6¾ in.) in total length and averages 1.4 gm in weight.<ref name=\"Wright&Wright1957\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: }}Jitender Singh 'Shunty' (born  1 August 1962), is an Indian [[politician]] and [[social work]]er. Shunty was elected as the Member of Legislative Assembly from [[Shahdara (Delhi Assembly constituency)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Shahdara]] from Bhartiya Janta Party in 2013.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column8: title=JITENDER SHIGH SHUNTY MLA of Shahdara Delhi contact address & email
column12: title=General Election 2013 - Candidate's Affidavit AC No. & Name:62 - SHAHDARA
column19: access-date=}}</ref> Jitender Singh Shunty is the founder of Shaheed Bhagat Singh Seva Dal, an NGO that helps to cremate unclaimed bodies and immerse the ashes as guided by the Hindu and Sikh religion.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column21: title=In Photos: Providing Dignity to the Dead By Claiming the Unclaimed

The '''women's featherweight''' is a competition featured at the [[2015 World Taekwondo Championships]], and was held at the [[Traktor Ice Arena]] in [[Chelyabinsk]], Russia on May 17 and May 18. Featherweights were limited to a maximum of 57 kilograms in body mass.

column3: Adforton's local parish church St Andrews.]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: '''Adforton''' is a small village and [[Civil parishes in England
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: civil parish]] in north [[Herefordshire]], England. It is located north of Wigmore, close to the Wales border, and is surrounded by agricultural fields.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: It has a church which doubles as a community hall. It is situated on the [[A4110 road

:\"a township with Stanway, Paytoe, and Grange, in the parish of Leintwardine, in Hereford 2 miles north west of Wigmore with a population of 250 people and 57 houses within the area,\"<ref>{{cite book
column9: accessdate=5 February 2015}}</ref> by John Marius Wilson's Imperial Gazetteer of England and Wales.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: It had a population of 128 according to the 2011 census.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Key figures for 2011 census: Key statistics

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Adforton provides a full programme of local events throughout the year to residents and visitors. Parish events include guided walks and village fetes. The local history clubs also provide talks about local life in the area from the past. Adforton is also a very keen society in terms of music. Open mic events are regularly put on in pubs, while more classical musical tastes can be satisfied in the local churches. Other events include sporting activities such as cycling, challenge events, orienteering and car rallying events in the countryside. The tourism industry benefits here and as a result a number of high quality holiday accommodations are available such as inns, cottages and bed and breakfast facilities that attract a lot of attention from visitors.<ref>{{cite web

column3: A map Designed in the 20th century by the Ordnance Survey, which shows the location of Adforton and its surroundings.]]
A scatter graph to show the population change in Adforton between 1881 and 2011.]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: St Andrews Church was designed and built in 1874 by an architect called J Gilmore. Until this Church was built there was only one other in Adforton, which was the Primitive Methodist Chapel built in 1863. The Royal George Inn is the only public house left in the village. It dates as far back as 1723, and tradition has it that the timbers used for construction, were taken from the ship 'The Royal George', and hence why the Inn is called what it is. However, due to the fact that the ship went down all hands off Spithead on 29 August 1782, so the story seems unlikely.<ref>{{cite web

Adforton is only a small parish, and as a result, it is hard to interpret whether any changes in the population have been significant or a consequence of an event or change in culture. However between 1881 and 2001, it has clearly fluctuated throughout the decades, but yet eventually been reduced from 204 to 118, which could be judged as a significant reduction for such a small area. From the census data we know that the peak population was in 1901 where the population sat at 215 people however then started to drop in the later decades. In 2001 it reached its lowest point within the time period at 118, however it has begun to rise again, as in 2011 the population was recorded at 128, which is what it sits at now. The reason for the drop pre 2011 may be a consequence of improvements in travel allowing for more people to live in the urban areas. Despite this a growing trend for commuting has occurred in the last decade, which may be why the population is beginning to rise again.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Key figures for 2011 census for Adforton: Population

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The census data for 1881 shows us that agricultural work was the dominant occupation amongst males at the time, as 32 men worked on farms and with animals etc. However, there were men employed in other occupations such as Professional jobs, furniture designers and lodging. As for females, the data shows that most occupations (29) were unspecified and another six were unknown, but despite this the occupation with the most women employed in it was domestic services/ offices. Women did still work in agriculture but not as much as males. The culture at this present time was a significant influence on the structure of workforces. At the time, the tradition was that the men would go out and work and bring in the money, whilst the women would stay at home and look after the children, which could explain why not as many women were involved in the workforce structure make up of Adforton.<ref>{{cite web

column3: The bar graph shows the number of males employed in different occupations in Adforton during 1881.]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: [[File:A bar graph showing the occupation of Women in Adforton..PNG
column3: The graph shows the occupation types and number of women employed in them from the census data of 1881.]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: [[File:A bar graph to show male occupation data for 2011 in Adforton..PNG
column3: This bar graph shows the occupation data for males living in Adforton from the 2011 census data.]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: [[File:A graph to show occupational data for females in 2011 in Adforton..PNG
column3: A bar graph to show occupational data for women in Adforton, using the 2011 census data.]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The types of occupation have obviously significantly changed over the decades, as new job opportunities have been brought to the people of Adforton. According to the 2011 census data, the occupation type with the most males working in it from the parish is jobs involved with skilled trades. Other occupations with a high count are Managers, directors and senior officials, and professionals with a 6 males each employed within them. The occupations with the lowest counts are sales and customer service and Administrative and secretarial occupations.  For women the occupations with the highest counts are Administrative and Secretarial services with 8 while the lowest is professional occupations. Since 1881, a lot has changed in the social attitudes related to occupational trends throughout the whole country. Improvements in women's rights have led to more women being employed in the same jobs as men, which therefore explains the clear differentiations from the occupational statistics for 1881, in comparison to 2011.<ref>{{cite web
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: title=Occupation data for Adforton- Females, 2011 census.
column6: title=Occupation data for Adforton: Males, 2011 census.

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su:
known_for = [[Grenfell Mission]]
[[Military Cross]]
[[Croix de Guerre]]
[[Military chaplain
column4: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]]

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: MC]] (1889-1964) was a British soldier and priest.  He served as an Officer in the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] during [[World War I]] for which he was [[mentioned in despatches]], awarded a [[Military Cross]] and the [[Croix de Guerre]], as Captain and subsequently Major of his Regiment.<ref name=\"auto6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Life story: Arthur Raley | Lives of the First World War
column7: title=Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador, volume 2 [Extract: letter Hac-Hoy] :: Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador
column13: title=A History of the Church Lads' Brigade in Newfoundland
column18: via=Google Books}}</ref>  After the [[World War I
column19: War]] he was ordained in [[England]] and later became [[Military chaplain
column21: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he held the relative rank of Squadron Leader and was again [[mentioned in despatches]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref name=\"auto\">https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf</ref><ref name=\"auto4\">https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/34636/page/4049/data.pdf</ref>  Prior to [[World War I]], Raley worked on the [[Grenfell Mission]] in [[Labrador]], [[Canada]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Arthur Raley was born at [[Barnsley]], [[England]] in 1889.<ref name=\"auto5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  He was educated at [[Bedford Modern School]] where, as an accomplished cricketer, he was in the first XI in 1905 and 1906.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Community: Bedford Modern School - Eagle Magazine extracts | Lives of the First World War
column11: website=livesofthefirstworldwar.iwm.org.uk}}</ref>  He played in a cricket match with [[W. G. Grace]] shortly after leaving school.<ref name=\"auto5\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: After school, Raley trained as a surveyor but gave it up and emigrated to [[Newfoundland]], [[Canada]], on his 21st birthday, with the ultimate aim of being ordained.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He initially worked as a schoolmaster at what is now [[Bishop Feild College]] in [[Newfoundland]] before joining the [[Grenfell Mission]] and being sent to northern [[Labrador]] where he took command of a reindeer ranch organising medical supplies and assistance to remote communities.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

Raley joined the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] but when [[World War I]] was declared, he signed up with the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] as a Lieutenant on 24 September 1914.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Lieutenant Owen William Steele of the Newfoundland Regiment
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  As part of the [[Mediterranean Expeditionary Force]] he saw action in [[Gallipoli]], having landed at [[Suvla Bay]], and was promoted Captain on 28 July 1915 and Adjutant on 29 September 1915.<ref name=\"auto7\"/><ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>{{Cite web

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was admitted to hospital in [[Malta]] on 13 December 1915 but rejoined the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Regiment]] at [[Suez]] on 31 January 1916.<ref name=\"auto7\"/>  His Regiment was part of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)
column3: British Expeditionary Force]] on 14 March 1916 and Raley was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 1 January 1917.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref name=\"auto7\"/>  The citation for his [[Military Cross]] read:'For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.  He organised and gallantly led a bombing attack driving the enemy back at a critical time.  He set a splendid example of courage and initiative'.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref>https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_0-149.pdf</ref>

column4: Capt. A Raley (left) leading the Royal Newfoundland Regiment across the Rhine into Germany, 1918]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was wounded at [[Monchy-le-Preux]] during the [[Battle of Arras (1917)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Battle of Arras]] in April 1917 after which he returned to [[England]] to convalesce.<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column9: via=Google Books}}</ref>  On 23 May 1917, he was attached to the Depot, Ayr, and rejoined his Regiment on 26 January 1918.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Following the Armistice, Captain Raley and Lt. Col. A.E. Bernard led the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] across the Rhine into Germany on 13 December 1918.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=www.heritage.nf.ca}}</ref>  He was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] in 1919.<ref>https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/31409/supplement/7805/data.pdf</ref>  He was appointed Second in Command of the 1st Battalion of his Regiment in May 1919 before his return to Newfoundland.<ref name=\"auto2\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: According to ''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]]'', Raley returned to England and entered [[St Boniface Missionary College, Warminster]], after which he was made Deacon of the Church of All Saints Luton where he became a Priest in 1924.<ref name=\"auto3\">{{Cite web
column6: via=Google Books}}</ref>  For the next fifteen years he worked as a parish priest at Christ Church Luton and as Vicar of Grimethorpe (1931-49).<ref name=\"auto2\"/><ref name=\"auto3\"/><ref>https://www.barnsleybenefice.org/content/pages/documents/1461176117.pdf</ref>

column3: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he was again [[mentioned in despatches]] and had the relative rank of Squadron Leader.<ref name=\"auto\"/><ref name=\"auto4\"/>  He left his Vicarship at Grimethorpe in 1949,<ref>The London Gazette, 8 March 1949, p.1203</ref> but remained Vicar of St Edward’s Church Barnsley until 1961.<ref name=\"auto3\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In 1960, Raley was honoured by his old school, being made President of the [[Bedford Modern School
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Old Bedford Modernians’ Club]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He died in [[Bedford]] in 1964.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column6: publisher=National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: [[Category:Canadian military personnel of World War I]]
[[Category:British military personnel of World War I]]
[[Category:British military personnel of World War II]]
[https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf Certain papers concerning Major Arthur Raley MC]","{{Use dmy dates

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: MC]] (1889-1964) was a British soldier and priest.  He served as an Officer in the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] during [[World War I]] for which he was [[mentioned in despatches]], awarded a [[Military Cross]] and the [[Croix de Guerre]], as Captain and subsequently Major of his Regiment.<ref name=\"auto6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Life story: Arthur Raley | Lives of the First World War
column7: title=Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador, volume 2 [Extract: letter Hac-Hoy] :: Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador
column13: title=A History of the Church Lads' Brigade in Newfoundland
column18: via=Google Books}}</ref>  After the [[World War I
column19: War]] he was ordained in [[England]] and later became [[Military chaplain
column21: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he held the relative rank of Squadron Leader and was again [[mentioned in despatches]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref name=\"auto\">https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf</ref><ref name=\"auto4\">https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/34636/page/4049/data.pdf</ref>  Prior to [[World War I]], Raley worked on the [[Grenfell Mission]] in [[Labrador]], [[Canada]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Arthur Raley was born at [[Barnsley]], [[England]] in 1889.<ref name=\"auto5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  He was educated at [[Bedford Modern School]] where, as an accomplished cricketer, he was in the first XI in 1905 and 1906.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Community: Bedford Modern School - Eagle Magazine extracts | Lives of the First World War
column11: website=livesofthefirstworldwar.iwm.org.uk}}</ref>  He played in a cricket match with [[W. G. Grace]] shortly after leaving school.<ref name=\"auto5\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: After school, Raley trained as a surveyor but gave it up and emigrated to [[Newfoundland]], [[Canada]], on his 21st birthday, with the ultimate aim of being ordained.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He initially worked as a schoolmaster at what is now [[Bishop Feild College]] in [[Newfoundland]] before joining the [[Grenfell Mission]] and being sent to northern [[Labrador]] where he took command of a reindeer ranch organising medical supplies and assistance to remote communities.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

Raley joined the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] but when [[World War I]] was declared, he signed up with the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] as a Lieutenant on 24 September 1914.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Lieutenant Owen William Steele of the Newfoundland Regiment
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  As part of the [[Mediterranean Expeditionary Force]] he saw action in [[Gallipoli]], having landed at [[Suvla Bay]], and was promoted Captain on 28 July 1915 and Adjutant on 29 September 1915.<ref name=\"auto7\"/><ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>{{Cite web

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was admitted to hospital in [[Malta]] on 13 December 1915 but rejoined the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Regiment]] at [[Suez]] on 31 January 1916.<ref name=\"auto7\"/>  His Regiment was part of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)
column3: British Expeditionary Force]] on 14 March 1916 and Raley was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 1 January 1917.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref name=\"auto7\"/>  The citation for his [[Military Cross]] read:'For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.  He organised and gallantly led a bombing attack driving the enemy back at a critical time.  He set a splendid example of courage and initiative'.<ref name=\"auto1\"/><ref>https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_0-149.pdf</ref>

column4: Capt. A Raley (left) leading the Royal Newfoundland Regiment across the Rhine into Germany, 1918]]

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Raley was wounded at [[Monchy-le-Preux]] during the [[Battle of Arras (1917)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Battle of Arras]] in April 1917 after which he returned to [[England]] to convalesce.<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column9: via=Google Books}}</ref>  On 23 May 1917, he was attached to the Depot, Ayr, and rejoined his Regiment on 26 January 1918.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: Following the Armistice, Captain Raley and Lt. Col. A.E. Bernard led the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] across the Rhine into Germany on 13 December 1918.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=www.heritage.nf.ca}}</ref>  He was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] in 1919.<ref>https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/31409/supplement/7805/data.pdf</ref>  He was appointed Second in Command of the 1st Battalion of his Regiment in May 1919 before his return to Newfoundland.<ref name=\"auto2\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: According to ''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]]'', Raley returned to England and entered [[St Boniface Missionary College, Warminster]] after which he was made Deacon of the Church of All Saints Luton where he became a Priest in 1924.<ref name=\"auto3\">{{Cite web
column6: via=Google Books}}</ref>  For the next fifteen years he worked as a parish priest at Christ Church Luton and as Vicar of Grimethorpe (1931-49).<ref name=\"auto2\"/><ref name=\"auto3\"/><ref>https://www.barnsleybenefice.org/content/pages/documents/1461176117.pdf</ref>

column3: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he was again [[mentioned in despatches]] and had the relative rank of Squadron Leader.<ref name=\"auto\"/><ref name=\"auto4\"/>  He left his Vicarship at Grimethorpe in 1949,<ref>The London Gazette, 8 March 1949, p.1203</ref> but remained Vicar of St Edward’s Church Barnsley until 1961.<ref name=\"auto3\"/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: In 1960, Raley was honoured by his old school, being made President of the [[Bedford Modern School
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Old Bedford Modernians’ Club]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He died in [[Bedford]] in 1964.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column6: publisher=National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

'''Parliamentary elections''' were held in [[Cyprus]] in 1960. The [[House of Representatives (Cyprus)
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: House of Representatives]] was elected on 31 July 1960,<ref>[[Dieter Nohlen]] & Philip Stöver (2010) ''Elections in Europe: A data handbook'', p438 {{ISBN
column3: 978-3-8329-5609-7}}</ref> whilst the [[Communal Chambers]] were elected on 7 August.<ref name=YO/> In the House of Representatives 35 seats were elected by [[Greek Cypriots]] and 15 by [[Turkish Cypriots]].<ref name=NS2>Nohlen & Stöver, p434</ref> The result was a victory for the [[Patriotic Front (Cyprus)
column4: Patriotic Front]], which won 30 of the 50 seats. In the Communal Chambers, the Patriotic Front won 20 of the 26 seats in the Greek Chamber, whilst the [[Cyprus Turkish National Union]] won all seats in the Turkish Chamber.

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The House of Representatives consisted of 35 Greek members and 15 Turkish members, whilst the Greek Communal Chamber had 26 members (of which three were reserved for minorities) and the Turkish Communal Chamber had 30.

The 1959 electoral law divided Cyprus into six multi-member constituencies. Voters could vote for as many candidates as there were seats in their constituency.<ref name=MWC/> The electoral system used was [[Plurality voting]].

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: Democratic Union]] led by [[Themistocles Dervis]] and [[Ioannis Clerides]] did not participate in the elections.<ref name=YO>Yitzhak Oron ''Middle East Record Volume 1, 1960'' The Moshe Dayan Centre, p225</ref><ref name=MWC>Marshall William Conley (1967) [http://digitalcommons.mcmaster.ca/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=6314&context=opendissertations Political Community and Social Conflict: Cyprus]</ref> The Democratic Union had opposed the 1959 electoral law, claiming it favoured the Patriotic Front.<ref name=MWC/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The Patriotic Front and [[Progressive Party of Working People
Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: AKEL]] formed a pact for the elections, with a pre-agreed split of 30 and 5 seats respectively.<ref name=MWC/>

,unsafe,A2Xee,"{{short description: The hastily formed Pancyprian Union of Fighters fielded 4 candidates, with 2 in Nicosia,1 in Kyrenia and 1 in Larnaca.
The Patriotic Front and AKEL pressured independent candidates to withdraw from the elections. As a result, the only female candidate, Kallistheni Maouni, withdrew her candidacy.
In Paphos the 3 candidates of the Patriotic Front and 1 candidate of AKEL were elected unopposed.<ref name=\"Eklektor\">{{cite web

In the fifteen Turkish seats, eight members of the [[Cyprus Turkish National Union]] ran unopposed in [[Nicosia]], [[Kyrenia]] and [[Larnaka]], whilst 8 independent candidates ran against the Cyprus Turkish National Union’s candidates in [[Famagusta]], [[Limassol]] and [[Paphos]].<ref>Nohlen & Stöver, p441</ref>
No elections were held for the Communal Chambers except for the Greek Cypriot members of Kyrenia. All other candidates were elected unopposed.<ref name=\"Eklektor\" />

Only child of the Duke and Duchess of Su: The votes' totals are based on the average number of votes received by each party (across all their candidates) in a constituency. The percentages are calculated based on the total valid votes rather than the total of average votes, meaning they total more than 100%.}}
